Ben,

Thank you very much for posting such detailed feedback.  This is exactly 
what we need to make sure that JUnit 4 will meet users' needs.  Just to 
give you an idea of what you can expect:

Ben Maurer wrote:
> Ant XML output
> --------------
> [...]
> However, in rc2, it looks like:
>
> <testcase classname="junit.framework.JUnit4TestAdapterCache$2$1" 
> name="unknown" time="0.018"></testcase>
That doesn't look good, does it?  If my initial guess as to this bug's 
source is correct, this will be easily fixed (back to rc1's behavior, at 
least) soon.
> Stack Trace Filtering
> ---------------------
>
> The stack trace from junit messages have always been filed with junit.*
> traces. Ant filters these out. However, now there are org.junit things
> slipping through. Also, tests with a timeout, have many
> java.util.concurrent frames in them. Why leave this kind of filtering up
> to each tool? JUnit should filter out the frames it knows are from it.
> This would make command line output look nicer. I think NUnit does this.
This is tricky.  The JUnit API actually reports the Exception objects to 
the tools, which are then responsible for displaying / parsing stack 
traces.  I don't know that there's anything we could do to make 
pre-JUnit 4 tools automatically filter the org.junit lines, but we might 
look at something for the future.
> @Test(expected=) traces
> -----------------------
>
> When you have an expected exception, and another one gets thrown, the
> error trace doesn't contain the bad exception. You only get:
>
> java.lang.AssertionError: Unexpected exception, 
> expected<java.util.NoSuchElementException> but 
> was<java.lang.NullPointerException>
>
> Having the trace of the bad exception would help TAs debug student code. 
That's a good idea.  We'll try to have that in the next release.

Thanks again--let us know what other issues you see, and good luck with 
the class!

    David Saff
